description.narrative: The project title is humanity and equality to accelerate rights through therapeutic theatre -HEART for 2016-2020. The aim is influencing discriminatory cultural and traditional attitudes with harmful practices towards women and girls through creating awareness on masculinity and gender stereotypes to combat gender based violence in society. The total rights holders are 6,355 and (female 3664, male 2691). The fact of violence against adolescents and women are common in our country. Social values never consider the patterns behaviour as rights violation. So the raising voice on GBV. Law and law enforcement agency is inadequate to address the issue. Domestic violence and gender discrimination are easily becoming victims of trafficking. The situation keeps them apart from gender rights. UTSA considers the phenomenon of human rights violation on psychosocial aspects and feels those as root causes of mental imbalance of adolescents frequently. The major results are a positive environment achieved towards implementation of human rights considering psychosocial rights and gender based violation, a positive attitude and circumstance exists in favouring gender equality at duty bearer and positive attitude is present at schools, college and community, ensured access of young, GBV, and mental health victims in employment. The major activities are forming and organizing different groups/forums like adolescent and youth forum, guardian forum, mental health advocacy association, women network and theatre therapist group. Organizing orientation on gender, family law, HR, SRHR, CRC, CEDAW and life skill education and study circle on mental health and psychotherapy/theatre therapy/therapeutic theatre technique. Organizing psychosocial care camp and advocacy meeting and different day observation. Organizing sports and creative art competition and debate for adolescents and youth, self-defence training for girls. Provide legal support, help line service and record keeping of GBV.
This project mainly contributes to results within Combating gender based violence. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
